title: #304 Accelerating Data Science | Nick Becker & Dan Hannah | NVIDIA & SES AI

rawLines.text: Welcome to dataf framed. This is Richie.
A brilliant thing about data science is
that it can be used to solve difficult
technical problems that benefit the
whole world. Today we're going to look
at how data science is used to find new
battery electrolyte chemistries. Since
batteries are in almost every gadget
these days, if we have lighter or
smaller or cheaper batteries, it's going
to benefit almost everyone on a daily
basis. I've got two fantastic guests for
you. First up is Dan Hannah, the
associate director for materials
discovery at SCES AI. Dan's got a
fascinating career at the intersection
of data science and chemistry. So he
leads a team creating AI models that he
used to hunt for new battery
electrolytes. Nick Becka is a technical
product manager at NVIDIA. So he runs
the team that's developing the rapid
software suite. That means he's trying
to bring GPU computing to the masses of
datamists and data scientists. So let's
see how these two stories of hunting for
battery electrolytes and of GPU
computing intertwine. These physics
based simulations in most cases, they
don't tell you whether the molecule is
going to be good in a battery. There
there's, you know, we're not there yet.
At the end of the day, the only way to
know the molecule is good in a battery
is to go put it in a battery. But it can
tell you pretty well with with sort of a
pretty high degree of fidelity whether a
molecule is going to be bad in a
battery. GPUs are great for AI and if
you're using, you know, AI frameworks,
of course, it makes sense to use um, you
know, accelerated computing and GPUs,
but it's not as obvious sometimes why it
actually makes sense. If you're doing
data frames or clustering or machine
learning or graph analytics, why did
GPUs help there, too? GPUs and
accelerated computing are really welld
designed for parallel processing. And it
turns out that a lot of problems had
latent parallelism that's not quite as
clear on first glance, but when you
decompose the problem becomes actually
very
obvious. Hi there, Nick. Hi there, Dan.
Welcome to the show. Hey Richie. Hey.
Good to be here. Brilliant. So to begin
with, I'd love to hear the story about
searching for new batteries. So Dan, uh,
just tell me what does looking for a new
battery involve? There's actually a lot
of moving parts that go into discovering
a new battery. And some of those are my
focus area and others are are something
that's being done by other people at the
company or other companies just kind of
depending on what part of the geometry
and the architecture of the hardware
you're talking about. So, I I'll give a
really quick overview of the sort of
different ways that you kind of plug
into the art of discovering a new
battery and then I'll talk a little bit
more specifically about what SCES and my
team at SCES is doing. So, overall, if
you want to make a battery better,
ultimately that usually means you either
want it to last longer. So, if you're
talking about an electric vehicle, I
want to drive for a longer distance in
between charges, or I want to improve
some other performance related aspect of
that battery. So that might mean for a
given amount of weight I would like to
get more energy out or maybe I'd like
the battery to perform better at higher
or lower temperatures for example. So
with all of these sort of performance
metrics there's different ways you can
go about trying to improve the battery.
So in some cases those improvements are
more at a hardware level. For example,
if I can develop a more efficient way of
packing battery cells into a hardware
enclosure, I can get more energy for a
given volume. And so that's that's sort
of a hardware level improvement. On the
other hand, there are more fundamental
improvements as well that are related to
the materials that we choose to make the
battery out of. So a great recent
example of this has been a shift towards
making batteries out of iron instead of
say nickel, manganese, and cobalt which
are sort of these rare expensive
minerals that we anticipate kind of
creating a lot of squeeze on. And so
you've seen that there's been this big
shift towards what people call LFP. That
stands for lithium iron phosphate. Iron
is a lot cheaper. It's a lot more
readily available. And this is
fundamentally an achievement on kind of
the material science side of batteries.
We discovered a new material that we
think can give us satisfactory
performance at a much lower cost with
some added performance benefits as well.
And it's the the material science aspect
of this that that SCES especially kind
of my corner of SCES is really focused
on. And in our case, what we're trying
to do is improve what's called the
electrolyte. So the electrolyte is the
liquid in in sort of a conventional
battery architecture. The electrolyte is
the liquid that's in the middle of a
battery. So if you take a battery out of
any device in your house, like a battery
is going to have a a negative side, a
positive side, and we usually refer to
those as the anode and cathode
respectively. And then there's liquid in
the middle. And that liquid in the
middle is the electrolyte. And it has a
few very important properties, some of
which are often at odds with one another
that need to be simultaneously
optimized. So today, um, especially for
a lot of next generation battery
chemistries, these are things that, um,
you'll often hear called lithium metal
batteries or silicon anode batteries.
The reason we develop these batteries is
because they offer a much higher energy
density. So what that means is that
fundamentally if I make a car battery
out of one of these things, my car can
drive a lot farther uh between charges
for a given kind of size or weight of
that battery. The problem is that these
high energy density
materials pose a big challenge for the
electrolyte
because sort of by virtue of the fact
that they store a lot of energy, they
are likely to want to give up some of
that energy in the form of a chemical
reaction with that liquid in the middle
of the battery. And so fundamentally we
think of the
electrolyte as the sort of limiting
factor in being able to productionize
these more advanced battery materials.
So for for the the anode and the
cathode, we have good solutions. We know
what we would like to do. We would like
to use either pure lithium metal or
silicon for the the sort of anode. And
for the cathode, I I spoke to this
advancement earlier, but you're seeing a
lot of people gravitating towards
lithium iron phosphate. And so there's
been some developments for for sort of
the two ends of the battery. And then
that liquid in the middle kind of
remains a lingering challenge that we
haven't solved yet. And so at SCS, what
I'm trying to do is figure out what
should we make that liquid out of. And
for when when we kind of zoom way into
to what I specifically am working on,
I'm trying to discover new molecules
that we can make that electrolyte out
of. So some people do what's called
formulation optimization and that's a
different but but also very important
part of making that electrolyte. So
formulation optimization is when you
know I I sort of have a sense of what
ingredients I would like to use. I'm
just sort of trying to figure out what
ratio uh I would I would like to combine
them in or in some cases would I like to
add in additional things that may
improve the performance in in useful
ways. And then kind of even even sort of
one step more fundamental than that than
that is what ingredients should I be
using? Are there new ingredients out
there that are going to be a quantum
leap in making that electrolyte more
stable? And at SCS, we believe the
answer to that question is yes. That's
kind of our fundamental bet is that
somewhere out there in what we call the
molecular universe, there are molecules
that would be a better choice for the
electrolyte. And the reason we believe
that is because if you really dive in
and you look at what has been done in
the past, you know, few decades, we've
really only explored in in kind of a
principled detailed
way maybe a few hundred maybe a thousand
on the high end different molecules to
be used in this electrolyte. And one of
the reason that's been so slow is that
for a long time the only way we could
investigate these molecules was to
procure them either by synthesizing them
or buying them going into the lab in
some cases actually putting them in a
battery and measuring their performance.
But as
essentially both our our kind of
theoretical understanding of how these
molecules behave and our sort of access
to computing power has increased
exponentially which is one of the
reasons we're talking here today. it's
actually become easier to get a much
better sense of how these molecules will
perform just on a computer before you
ever do anything in the laboratory. And
so with with kind of the advent of
computational material science and the
the sort of accelerant that ML and AI h
have been able to to provide and make
computational material science go even
faster than it used to. we're now at a
point where we feel like we can start to
meaningfully explore the molecular
universe and maybe find some of those
key winners. So, I'll pause there. U
obviously happy to elaborate, but that
that I think is sort of the the process
that that that we're engaged in as as we
try to improve batteries at the sort of
molecular level. Okay. Thank you. So,
that's such a fascinating problem. You
got batteries in almost everything from
cars to bikes to almost every kind of
gadget. And so I can certainly see how
having a lighter battery or a smaller
battery or something that's cheaper. But
uh there are an awful lot of things you
might to operize around these batteries
and it sounds like an awful lot of this
um is material design, there's a lot of
chemistry, there's a lot of physics. Can
you go into more detail on what the data
science involves and where does
computation come in? Yeah, absolutely.
So, so as a as you noted at at sort of
the beginning of this, we we were taking
a physics and chemistrydriven approach
to this problem. We, you know, way back,
a lot of this is just driven by human
intuition. This is people who went to
school for chemistry and physics and
chemical engineering and things like
that just applying what they had learned
in courses to try and sort of rationally
design the best formulation or the best
molecule for this task. Then computers
got a little better and our theory got a
little better and we got to a point
where we can run sort of physics driven
simulations of how these molecules will
perform in a battery and that was great
for a while. But if you think about how
fast these simulations go and or really
what I mean is how long they take to run
on a computer and you think about the
size of the molecular universe which for
for our kind of purposes you could think
about it as as sort of a few hundred
billion molecules probably and I can I
can sort of unpack that but you know
applying kind of some some common sense
constraints to the size of the space
you're still looking at about a few
hundred billion potential candidates
and the the speed of sort of explicitly
uh simulating those by the laws of
physics, it it would actually take way
too long even with our current sort of
computing architecture and and hardware.
And so that's where the data science
comes in. That's where the machine
learning comes in. We need a way to both
sort of winnow down the number of
molecules we'd actually like to give
more scrutiny to and at the same time we
also need a way to consider these huge
data sets holistically. So if you know
if I if I want to make a judgment call
about a set of 100 billion molecules
it's really the data science provides
the tools of the trade for drawing
conclusions about you know what is the
distribution of some property um within
a particular corner of this data set and
and so that's one piece is just even
analyzing this data set actually
requires some non-trivial data science.
The second piece where data science
really plays a key role is in allowing
us to sort of bypass these expensive
physical simulations where instead of
explicitly simulating how a molecule
will behave in a battery, if I do that
for a large enough number of molecules
and I do that for sort of a sufficiently
diverse set of molecules, I can
reasonably train a machine learning
model that just predicts the answer I
want to within a useful degree of
accuracy. So a lot of times people in
the community will refer to these as
surrogate models rather than you know
running the physical simulation
explicitly. I'm actually just training a
machine learning model to give you the
answer you would have gotten from
running that simulation but much much
faster. And that that speed up which
which is often several orders of
magnitude. These are these are sort of
non-trivial speed ups we're talking
about.
That speed up is really key to allowing
us to access those scales of hundreds of
billions, billions, hundreds of billions
where we can sort of credibly claim to
have exhaustively explored a space to
find the best candidates for a given
application. And that's true for
batteries, but that's also true for
various biological applications and
various other kinds of molecular u
technologies.
Okay. Um, I'd love to talk a little bit
about the technology you're using. I
know you're using Nvidia technology. So,
uh, Nick, do you want to talk about how
NVIDIA tech is supporting this search
for better electrolytes?
Yeah, absolutely. Um, so I think one of
the the big pieces here is that Nvidia
technology is broad and it's really
built on top of the CUDA platform and on
top of this CUDA platform which many
folks are likely familiar with um
Nvidia's CUDA there's a whole ecosystem
of what we call CUDA libraries or CUDA X
libraries hundreds of libraries and so
in this space um one ecosystem of
libraries is called rapids it's a set of
libraries that are open source designed
to bring accelerated computing into the
world of data science and machine
learning to complement how the world of
AI already has that acceleration um that
we've built up over the past, you know,
10 years as a community. And so this
rapids ecosystem has libraries for
tabular data processing, machine
learning, dimensionality reduction,
clustering, all of these different tools
um and techniques that, you know, folks
like Dan and then and Dan's teams can
tap into to be able to take the work
that they're doing with their CPU based
tools and go 10, 50, even hundreds of
times faster by using accelerated
computing on the NVIDIA platform. Um,
and what's really important with these
libraries is that you don't need to
reinvent the wheel. You don't need to
change your code. You can actually tap
into this using the tools you're already
familiar with by flipping the switch, so
to speak, and no code changes required.
Um, so this is just one part of the
ecosystem of Nvidia's accelerated
computing libraries and tools. Um,
there's other techniques and and more.
Um I'll mention one other in pass in
here um that you know that Dan and the
team at SCS are using called Nvidia
Alchemy which is really about making it
easier and effective to bring those AI
techniques to bear for all the work that
Dan was talking about just a few minutes
ago. And so the combination of things
like Nvidia Alchemy Rapids for
accelerated data science um there's a
whole bunch of different capabilities in
the NVIDIA Nemo platform and and
ecosystem of frameworks around how do
you actually prep the data for these AI
models. These are some of the
foundational pieces that are available
to everyone but in particular here we're
excited to work with Dan and Dan's team
to help explore the molecular universe.
I do like that phrase molecular
universe. Sounds very cool. Uh yeah.
Okay. So uh CUDA is your low-level tech
then for interfacing with the GPU for
doing broad computation on them and then
rapids is more of the data science
focused stuff that's on top of that. Um
I'd love to hear more about when do you
actually need a GPU? So what sort of
data science problems areable to GPUs?
When do you need this stuff? Yeah. So I
think this is actually a really
counterintuitive point for a lot of
people. You know, I think most of us, I
suspect most of listeners are aware
that, you know, GPUs are great for AI
and if you're using, you know, AI
frameworks, of course, it makes sense to
use um, you know, accelerated computing
and GPUs, but it's not as obvious
sometimes why it actually makes sense if
you're doing data frames or clustering
or machine learning or graph analytics.
Why did GPUs help there too? Uh, and it
turns out I think that the real key
insight here is that GPUs and
accelerated computing are really welld
designed for parallel processing. And it
turns out that a lot of problems have
latent parallelism that's not quite as
clear on first glance, but when you
decompose the problem becomes actually
very obvious. So a perfect example of
that would be know if you I think many
folks here likely have used structured
or tabular data before. Um if you're not
taking tabular data, you're processing
that data, maybe you're using your
favorite data frame library. U depending
on what you know programming frameworks
you use or your teams use, data frames
frequently need to be connected
together. If you imagine, you know,
people who are analyzing data from maybe
transactions or you know consumer app
applications or web impressions suddenly
you want to understand well how did the
weather in this city affect this? I need
to connect the weather data set to my
internal data set. That's often called a
join or a merge. And when you think
about that operation, you might be not
just connecting data sets that have a
few hundred rows or a thousand rows, but
it could be millions of rows or even
billions of rows in these data sets. And
it's a huge computational problem. And
that operation, that computational
problem has a ton of underlying
parallelism in it. You think about
joining data sets together. What you're
actually doing is taking columns in
different data sets, comparing rows in
one data set to rows in the other,
looking for matches. If they match,
you're going to, you know, take some
action, maybe connect them together. If
they're not, you'll move on. But each of
those comparisons is independent. And so
it turns out that type of pattern is
something that pops up all over the
place. whether you're doing AI, whether
you're doing clustering data frame
operations like joins and you know group
aggregations and more. And so what we've
done is build up over you know the the
last several years an ecosystem of
accelerated computing tools and
libraries that make it possible to tap
into that power of that parallelism you
can get with the CUDA platform on NVIDIA
systems without needing to be an expert.
you can stay in your favorite
programming languages like Python or you
like C++ or Apache Spark if you're in
that world and just flip the switch and
get going. Okay, so that's kind of
interesting. Uh the idea that something
as common as a join can be done in a
parallel way. I have to say trying to
reason about this myself sounds like
something that's very hard to do. So
what do you need to do if you need to
have this implicit parallelism? So, as a
perfect example of that, um, you talking
about dataf frames and and joins. If
you're using maybe some of the most
popular dataf frame libraries in Python
today, maybe you're using pandas, which
is maybe the the world's most popular
dataf frame library, or polars, one of
the more recent increasingly popular
libraries, or even in the Apache Spark
world for it's in a big data processing.
Whatever you're doing, you don't need to
worry about how to handle that implicit
underlying parallelism.
you can rely on the fact that we've done
the work to build this CUDA powered
foundation, the CUDA data frame world
and wrapped it up so that you can
actually just take advantage of it
whenever you want to go faster to
improve productivity or the other side
of that coin. If you have things that
are running expensively, using
accelerated computing can knock those
costs down. Okay, so I'm glad it's
something that's taken care of. I don't
need to worry about it myself. Very
reassuring. Um, okay. So uh I'd like to
give an overview of how you set this up.
So suppose you're using pandas already,
how do you switch to the rapids version?
So I think the first thing is if you're
using pandas already, awesome. You might
have your favorite workflow. Maybe
you're working on your laptop or a
desktop. Maybe you're in the cloud. But
as you start to think about data sets
getting bigger, that's when this starts
to become really powerful. And so as
your data sets are growing into the tens
of thousands, hundreds of thousands,
millions, sometimes billions of records,
and you heard Dan talk about, you know,
a molecular space of millions and
billions of candidates. At this point,
there's there's often no alternative.
And so what you can do then is
think where can my organization how can
my organization get access to NVIDIA
GPUs? And maybe that's through
centralized resources. Maybe you have a
data platform team. Maybe your
workstation or your desktop has in has
um an Nvidia GPU in it or you're in the
cloud. Wherever you want to do your
work, this ecosystem is ready for you.
And as soon as you want to make that
switch, no code changes required. You
just simply need to get up and running
on that system with an Nvidia GPU.
Whether you're in a container or running
bare metal, it's up to you. Just install
the packages and you're off to the
races.
Dan, do you want to talk us through um
examples of specific data science
problems you're solving and talk me
through how do you make use of rapids?
Yeah, absolutely. So, one one I I think
that is very relevant here which which
is sort of what drove us to initially
adopt rapids in our workflow was this
problem of applying dimensionality
reduction to a huge data set. So, what
is dimensionality reduction? So
dimensionality reduction means that I I
have a very high dimensional data set
and so that means that each row in my
data set is described by a large number
of columns effectively. So for like a
scatter plot you know an XY plot each
row in your data sets only described by
two columns your X value and your
Y-value. But when data sets get out to
very high number of dimensions so in our
case this is hundreds of dimensions. And
I can I can explain what the data set is
here in a moment. But fundamentally when
you want to visualize a data set like
that we can't see things in 500
dimensions. We think in two or three
dimensions when when we sort of reason
spatially and look at things. And so in
our case we were applying what's called
a dimensionality reduction technique. So
that's a way to take that sort of that
that 500 some dimensional space and
compress it down to two dimensions. And
the trick is doing it in a way that
preserves the structure from the
highdimensional space. So, so what that
means is that say if if two of my rows
of data are close together in the
highdimensional space, I'd like them to
be close together in the lowdimensional
space as well. And I I would sort of
like for all the structural elements to
be preserved. And there are a number of
different algorithms for doing this,
each of which has their own set of sort
of tradeoffs and
um you know advantages. And so a lot of
people are probably familiar with
principal component analysis or um TNE
which is which is sort of a a slightly
more advanced um and and it's sort of
solving a slightly different problem
that fundamentally they're both
dimensionality reduction techniques. So
we're applying a more recent one known
as umaps that stands for uniform
manifold approximation and projection
and but but the problem it's solving is
the same. It's how do I take this
highdimensional data set and compress it
down to two? And I I can I can sort of
talk very briefly about the reason we
wanted to do this just to provide a
little bit of context. So um I because I
actually think this is a really cool and
and sort of surprising problem. We
actually went down this road because we
were trying to figure out how to inject
human intuition into a pipeline we had
already fully automated. So in our first
version of this molecular discovery
pipeline, it was it was headless. It was
something where you would enter some
things on a command line and you would
get back a list of answers. And what we
were finding was that and there there
were all sorts of kind of machine
learning models and physics models kind
of chained together on the inside doing
various things to try and figure out
which molecules would be best, you know,
for your your query essentially. And we
were getting back a list of molecules
and we were kind of finding
that functionally they were all too
similar actually. Uh when we went and
discussed these results with our
experimental scientists, they said that
you know these are great but a lot of
these variations seem to be variations
on on kind of a similar motif. And
that's risky because if there's
something bad about that motif
fundamentally you you can't you're going
to waste a bunch of time if you screen
all 100 of those in the lab. So ideally
you want to increase the diversity of
the data set. You you want a lot of
different motifs represented to sort of
derisk that that massive time and
monetary investment of actually testing
these in the lab. And so we started to
we started down this road of trying to
automate that of saying well okay how do
we automate this idea of bringing in
different motifs. And it turns out that
chemical intuition is extremely
complicated. The the series of decisions
that an expert chemist makes in their
mind when evaluating a molecule. It it's
nuanced and it varies from molecule to
molecule. Even for a given property take
like melting point for example. the the
the sort of underlying physics that
determine one compound's melting point
may be different from the physics that
determine a different compound's melting
point. And so so effectively where we
landed was our experimental scientist
said, you know, for now this this idea
of like the appropriate amount of kind
of structural diversity in in kind of a
a lab an array of lab candidates. You
you just know it when you see it. And so
so now we had to think, okay, well, what
do we do? So, we actually needed a way
to allow our human scientists to inject
their chemical intuition into our
screening pipeline. So, we wanted to
bring some some sort of human feedback
into this. And to do that, we needed to
give our human scientists a way to look
at how all these molecules in the data
set related to one another. And that's
where we got into this business of
dimensionality reduction because
ultimately our pipeline produced a
fingerprint for each molecule. So a
fingerprint is basically an array of
numbers that describes each molecule. So
for those of for those of you who might
be coming at this from more of a machine
learning or data science background, you
can think about word tovec, right? Word
tovec has something called an embedding
space. That embedding space describes
each word with an array of numbers. So
that's that's like, you know, you can
pull out the latent space of your neural
network and see that oh each word has a
representation um that's just these
parameters. And so the molecular
fingerprint is no different. It's a it's
a huge series of numbers that that we
trained to generate an optimal
representation of each molecule of the
data set. And so in our case, these were
specifically fingerprints trained to
capture um chemical structure. And so we
thought, okay, well maybe the right way
to do this is to give our human
scientists a map that they can actually
navigate. They could say, well, here's
one area of the chemical and sort of
structural space. Maybe we've adequately
sampled it if we just pluck a couple out
of it. So now I want to move somewhere
else. But the relationships that govern
chemical structure are sort of complex
and in many cases second and third order
sorts of interactions. And so so that's
why we we kind of wanted to build a map
that was based on these rich
representations. And so in order for our
scientists to actually visualize that,
that's where this came in. So we wanted
to take this 512th dimensional data set
and squash it down to something our
scientists could look at a scatter plot.
And that's where UMAP comes in. Here's
the problem. The molecular universe is
big. Even for a subset of molecules,
even if you sort of zoom in on a very
specific application and a very specific
use case, you're still looking at
oftentimes tens of millions of rows of
data. And the the problem with UMAP is
that or problem is maybe too too strong
a term but one of the challenges with
UMAP is that you do not know a priori
what parameters are going to be best.
Often times with these unsupervised
clustering approaches what you're really
looking for um or I should say
dimensionality reduction um with clust
clustering is part of this but that
comes later. Um, with these
dimensionality reduction techniques,
you're kind of looking for a result that
matches your intuition. You have some
kind of intuitive sense of how you would
like to see this data and you need to
find the parameters that that sort of
match that intuition. And so, so what
you need to do, what does it amount to
computationally? It's a parameter sweep.
I need to take the adjustable parameters
in this UMAP algorithm and I I need to
either do a grid search or do other some
kind some other kind of searching in
order to find the best parameters for my
data set. And so here this this is why
UMAP got complicated because on our data
with this sort of five you know hundreds
of of dimensions and millions in some
cases tens of millions of
rows running UMAP on a CPU would take
four to five sometimes six hours for a
single run. And if you think about a
grid search over three adjustable
parameters, that becomes prohibitive.
And with kind of the pace of materials
development at SCES and the types of
problems we're trying to solve, it was
basically a non-starter to sync over a
hundred sort of computing hours into
every data set that we needed to
investigate. And so we were sunk in
terms of that approach. You know, we
were very excited about this idea, but
scaling it seemed impossible. And that's
